### Describe the bug

Unclear if this should be a bug or feature request.

If you have data points on a Pin Map viz that span the 180th meridian, and you click on `Draw box to filter` and select them with a region like so:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/06892a03-871e-4acf-b538-2bb88acde452)

Rather than zooming in on the selected points / region as you'd expect, the map will instead zoom out, which is disorienting / confusing:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/65849d58-60eb-4507-b663-34665d431ba0)

Zooming out one more level makes it more clear that these points are actually located on opposite sides of the eastern/western hemispheres.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7069ba41-9a69-4697-b7d2-371695e19714)

Note that prior to the fix for https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/41056 this would result in a different bug where only the single point in the western hemisphere would be selected, so you need the fix for #41056 (now in master) for the above behavior to reproduce.

Slack link with loom (skip to the end): https://metaboat.slack.com/archives/C0645JP1W81/p1738960382927599

See also: https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/41056
Somewhat related: https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/5211



### To Reproduce

If you have a metabase dev env, the easiest way to reproduce is to first load some additional data into the People table in the Sample Database with some datapoints points in NZ.

* Download version of [h2 jar](https://github.com/h2database/h2database/releases/download/version-2.1.214/h2-2022-06-13.zip) that matches current metabase (currently 2.1.214)
* Download the attached [nz-people-sample.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/18833022/nz-people-sample.zip) and extract to nz-people-sample.sql
* Run the following commands from the Metabase source root to update the Sample Database where `~/Downloads/jars` is the path to wherever you downloaded the h2 jar. Note that the name of the file in the url you pass to h2 is `sample-database.db` **not** `sample-database.db.mv.db` even though the latter is the name of the file on your filesystem!
    * `rm plugins/sample-database.db.*`
    * `java -cp ~/Downloads/jars/h2-2.1.214.jar org.h2.tools.RunScript -url jdbc:h2:file:./resources/sample-database.db -script /tmp/nz-people-sample.sql`
* start your metabase as usual, e.g. `yarn dev` or whatever you normally do

Assuming your Sample DB now has the NZ data

1. New > Question > Sample Database > People
2. Visualize
3. Visualization > Map > Pin Map
4. Scroll south west to NZ
5. Click on `Draw box to filter` in the upper right corner of the map
6. Select a region that includes all NZ points, *including the single point on the small island in the western hemisphere* (see screenshot above)




### Expected behavior

You'd probably expect this to zoom in to the region you selected with the selected points still next to each other on the map, rather than zooming out to view that spans the globe with the points on opposite sides.

v53. Also present before, but obscured by the bug in #41056

### Describe the bug

Pin maps do not display records if the coordinates are incomplete. However, a card on a dashboard can only be hidden if the underlying question returns an empty result set. 

This opens an edge case - when results exist but the coordinates are incomplete, and the card remains visible. 
We should consider displaying a warning in this case to clarify why the card does not disappear, as users might expect it to if there are perceived to be no results.

1. Create a data set with coordinates where each record has an incomplete coordinate (one of the values or both are null)

3. Set 'Hide this card if there are no results' for this card on the dashboard
4.(!) The card remains to be visible, in a blank state, showing 'No results!'.

The current behavior is confusing. 
We should consider displaying a message on a blank card that reads, 'No displayable records. N records are hidden due to incomplete coordinates.' This would clarify why results are not being shown, despite their presence.

A possible workaround is to filter out records with empty coordinates from the dataset. However, it might be more beneficial to display a warning to keep the user informed about the presence of such records, which could be valuable information that would otherwise remain unknown.

body:
### Describe the bug

Pie charts and Funnel charts both are “sensible” if and only if the number of columns in the data is exactly 2. If there are more than two columns, the charts types are no longer “sensible”. This means that if the display type is pie chart and there are two columns in the data, and then later the query changes so the data has more than 2 columns, the pie chart no longer is "sensible" and the chart will switch back to a table chart, even if the chart is perfectly fine.

### To Reproduce

1. Create a new query with two columns, and make a pie or funnel chart. Save the question
2. Add a third column to the query and visualize the results. The chart type will have switched to a table.

Demo here:
https://www.loom.com/share/881d0e85bb0d442eb4b97ec2e06e167f?sid=b203a356-dcfc-4e43-bf71-b13e0f795107

### Expected behavior

Pie and funnel charts shouldn't switch to a different chart type automatically when data changes from 2 columns to more than 2 columns. They should only switch when the data changes from 2+ columns to 1 column.

comments.body: For Pie chart specifically, this would be solved by the ECharts migration (https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/33281), during which we would add series breakouts (aka [sunburst chart](https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/editor.html?c=sunburst-simple)). Thus I wouldn't recommend fixing it now, given that behavior will change.

Also, I think this fix requires more than allowing data with 2 or more columns to be plotted. As the data is not automatically aggregated like other charts, it can lead to some non-sensible charts - multiple slices represent the same category (e.g.if data is `grouped by`).

---
**No Auto-Aggregation in Pie/Funnel Charts**

![does-not-aggregate-in-pie-charts](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/assets/22608765/c87b1bbf-090d-40d0-85c3-73afed393531)

Could reproduce:

https://github.com/metabase/metabase/assets/22608765/1169d9fc-053a-4ccc-8cc5-aa7f7048d71f

---
Note: the changes for this would be a little more involved then just changing the sensibility check as pie charts/funnel charts do not auto-aggregate data, so this could lead to some funky charts (see [comment](https://github.com/metabase/metabase/issues/33113#issuecomment-1690382409))

body:
**Describe the bug**
Viewers of questions with a different locale than the creator's may see slightly differences in series visualization due to the way we store series settings. This is a problem for international teams that include people from different countries who use different locales. It will be impossible for them to see certain questions in the same way.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. New -> Question -> Orders -> Visualize
2. Summarize -> Group by "Created At: by month" and "Products -> Category"
3. Go to Settings -> Data
4. Make X-axis dimension "Products -> Category", breakout dimension "Created At: by month", Y-axis "Count"
5. For better readability, add a filter "Created at" after `09/15/2019`
6. Go to Settings -> Display 
7. Change any series settings: title, color, line style, etc.
8. Save the question
9. Go to Account Settings, change your locale to Chinese, and reload the page
10. Go to the question and observe that you've lost all your series settings

**Expected behavior**
The question should look the same

**Technical details**
When questions have breakouts, we use **formatted** break-out values as keys of `visualization_settings.series_settings` object which stores individual series titles, colors, etc. This is incorrect and the keys should ignore the language settings, any formatting and be a combination of raw values plus binning and bucketing configuration.

**Describe the bug**
When a field with remapping - either plain or as Grouped By, then the remapped display values are not shown in the X-axis ticks of Line/Bar/Area/Scatter, but instead the original column value is shown. The value is correctly shown in Row and Table.
This is caused by "X-axis scale"="Linear" by default instead of forcing "Ordinal", which also means that no sorting can be used, since Linear and Histogram have forced-sorting.

**To Reproduce**
1. Admin > Data Model > Sample Dataset > Orders > Product ID :gear: > "Display values"="Use foreign key" as "Title"
2. Simple question > Sample Dataset > Orders
3. Summarize Count by Orders.ProductID - and Filter Count greater than 110 - and click Count column to sort ascending.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1447303/99154005-bb16dc00-26ac-11eb-87c0-65b507470698.png)
4. Changing visualization to Line/Bar/Area/Scatter shows the IDs in the X-axis ticks instead of the remapped value, but hovering the data point shows the correct remapped value in the tooltip.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1447303/99154025-ec8fa780-26ac-11eb-8fc6-d4a23196ba48.png)
5. Setting "X-axis scale"="Ordinal" fixes the spacing, tick labeling and sorting

**Describe the bug**
Using pin maps on a data set that is wide, can be columns joined in the query builder, or simply a table with lots of columns. If you zoom in using either the "+" button or double clicking the map, then hover a pin to get more info the map zoom and pan is reset to default.

**Logs**
No logs created.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. "Ask a question" > "Custom Question"
2. "Sample Dataset" > "Orders"
3. Setup as below, mainly just to get a wide dataset with lots of columns
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4504437/67449572-1bd51000-f677-11e9-9005-9624ee2b6dcb.png)

4. "Visualize" > then set to pin map
5. Use "+" button on map to zoom in a couple of times
6. Hover a pin and the zoom is reset to the default

**Expected behavior**
I expect the zoom level to be retained when I hover a pin to get more info

**Information about your Metabase Installation:**

You can get this information by going to Admin -> Troubleshooting.

- Your browser and the version: Chrome Version 77.0.3865.120 (Official Build) (64-bit)
- Your operating system: Windows
- Your databases: MS SQL
- Metabase version: v0.33.4
- Metabase hosting environment: Jar file on Windows Server
- Metabase internal database: Postgres

**Severity**
Frustration, you can spend a bit of time zooming in on the area of interest then hover a pin for more detail and boom you're back where you started.

**Additional context**
This doesn't seem to be 100% reproducible. I've consistently seen it in all versions of Metabase that I've used, but I'm trying it now an it's not doing it. It was just 20 min ago on the same setup ...

title: Pin map only show pins once, but it's possible to pan to the wrong direction, so it does not show pins

body: Since Leaflet can only do integer "zoom" levels and the bounds of the points don't usually fall nicely on the predefined zoom levels, we need to either: 1. zoom out a little too far and have blank space around the pins (call it "viewport contains bounds") ``` +-------------+ | | | * | | | | ** | | * | | | +-------------+ ``` 2. zoom a little too far and hide some data points on the edges (call it "bounds contains viewport") ``` * +-----+ | ** | +-----+* ``` viewport-contains-bounds looks bad when there's a filter and a dense set of pins: bounds-contains-viewport might hide data points, and in the worst case it could hide *all* datapoints: ``` * +-----+ | | +-----+* ``` I think a possible compromise is to only use `bounds-contains-viewport` if a filter is applied and there are a certain number of points.

comments.body: @tlrobinson May I work on this? Thanks!
Maybe I'm missing something but `viewport contains bounds` does not look bad to me, and seems far better than the alternative of missing points, which could lead to mistaken analysis.
